US$8 billion was raised.[97]The European Commission issued a new multi-year data plan in February 2020 pushing the digitalization of all aspects of EU society for the benefit of civic and economic growth.[98][99][100][101]The goal of this data strategy is to create a single market for data in which data flows across the EU and across sectors while maintaining full respect for privacy and data protection, where access rules are fair, and where the European economy benefits enormously as a global player as a result of the new data economy.[98][99][100][101]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The European Commission addressed both health and digital priorities, organizing a video conference of world leaders on May 4, 2020, which successfully raised US$8 billion for COVID-19 vaccine development. Furthermore, in February 2020, the Commission issued a new multi-year data plan designed to digitalize all aspects of EU society. This strategy aims to create a single market for data across the EU, ensuring fair access rules and respecting privacy while positioning the European economy as a global player.
standaloneFacts: The European Commission organized a video conference of world leaders on 4 May 2020 to raise funds for COVID-19 vaccine development.
US$8 billion was raised during the European Commission's video conference for COVID-19 vaccine development.
The European Commission issued a new multi-year data plan in February 2020.
The multi-year data plan aims to promote the digitalization of all aspects of EU society for the benefit of civic and economic growth.
The goal of the European Commission's data strategy is to create a single market for data across the EU.
The data strategy mandates maintaining full respect for privacy and data protection.

segmentAnalyses.segment: LocationHeadquarters of the European Commission in Brussels (Berlaymont building)The commission's political seat is in Brussels with the President's office and the commission's meeting room on the 13th floor of the Berlaymont building. The commission also operates out of numerous other buildings in Brussels and Luxembourg City.[102][103] When the Parliament is meeting in Strasbourg, the Commissioners also meet there in the Winston Churchill building to attend the Parliament's debates.[104] The Members of the Commission and their "cabinets" (immediate teams) are also based in the Berlaymont building in Brussels. Additionally, the European Commission has in-house scientific facilities that support it in: Ispra, Italy; Petten, Netherlands; Karlsruhe, Germany; Geel, Belgium and Seville, Spain. In Grange, County Meath, Ireland, a Commission site is hosting part of DG Santè.
segmentAnalyses.summary: The European Commission's primary political seat is the Berlaymont building in Brussels, where the President's office and Commission meeting room are located on the 13th floor. While operations extend to other buildings in Brussels and Luxembourg City, Commissioners also meet in the Winston Churchill building in Strasbourg when the Parliament is in session. Additionally, the Commission maintains in-house scientific facilities in Ispra (Italy), Petten (Netherlands), Karlsruhe (Germany), Geel (Belgium), and Seville (Spain), alongside a site for part of DG Santè in Grange, County Meath, Ireland.
standaloneFacts: The European Commission's political seat is located in Brussels, specifically in the Berlaymont building.
The President's office and the European Commission's meeting room are located on the 13th floor of the Berlaymont building.
The European Commission operates out of numerous buildings in Brussels and Luxembourg City.
When the Parliament meets in Strasbourg, European Commissioners meet in the Winston Churchill building.
The Members of the European Commission and their immediate teams ("cabinets") are based in the Berlaymont building in Brussels.
The European Commission has in-house scientific facilities in Ispra, Italy.
The European Commission has in-house scientific facilities in Petten, Netherlands.
The European Commission has in-house scientific facilities in Karlsruhe, Germany.
The European Commission has in-house scientific facilities in Geel, Belgium.
The European Commission has in-house scientific facilities in Seville, Spain.
A Commission site in Grange, County Meath, Ireland, hosts part of DG Santè.
